Award.AwardTitle: Are All Active Galactic Nuclei Born Equal? The Silicate Dust Mineralogy Perspective
Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will analyze over 100 IRS archival spectra from the Spitzer Space Telescope with the objective of understanding infrared emission from dust structures in active galactic nuclei (AGN). The investigation will address a number of important questions about dust in AGN, and will determine if the simplistic dust torus plus orientation explanation for the differences between Seyfert Type 1 and Type 2 galaxies requires significant revision.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergrad and graduate students, and outreach to local K-12 schools by educating students on cutting-edge astronomy topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For some galaxies, their nuclei (or central cores), known as “active galactic nuclei" (AGN), emit more power than the entire rest of the galaxy. In some cases, the size of the AGN is smaller than the size of our solar system. How can AGN produces so much energy in such a small size (which is millions times smaller than the galaxy)? what is the central engine of AGN? This is one of the biggest mysteries in astrophysics. Current theory suggests that there is a supermassive black hole (millions of times more massive than our Sun) at the center of AGN. There appears to be a quiet supermassive black hole in the center of the Milky Way. A black hole is an object predicted by Einstein's general relativity theory of which the gravitational field is so strong that nothing can escape it, not even light. The power source in AGN is thought to be the energy generated by matter falling onto the central supermassive black hole. The AGN is surrounded by a dusty torus. The dust grains in the torus are heated by the X-ray and ultraviolet photons from the AGN and reradiate in the infrared. Infrared (IR) studies of dust have become a primary tool for many issues in AGN research. They are particularly useful in helping us to figure out what is going on in an AGN, since they can penetrate from far within the center of a galaxy.

Supported by this NSF/AST grant, we have studied the physical and chemical properties of the dust grains in the AGN torus. We have modeled the IR emission spectra of about 150 AGNs obtained by the Spitzer Space Telescope, with special attention paid to the 9.7 and 18μm silicate vibrational spectral features. The size, composition, temperature and spatial distribution of the dust in these AGNs were constrained and then compared with that of the Milky Way galaxy. We found that for AGNs, the obscuration of light by dust torus is more or less wavelength independent (i.e., “gray”), while in the Milky Way it is strongly wavelength dependent (i.e., it absorbs and scatters more light in the ultraviolet than the visible and near-IR). Our studies on the dust temperature constrained the size of the AGN dusty torus to be several parsecs (1 parsec is about 3.26 light-years or 30 trillion km or 19 trillion miles in length). We have also explored whether (and how) the dust properties may correlate with the AGN properties. We found that the dust masses are correlated with the AGN bolometric luminosity, while the dust masses and the black hole masses are not correlated. Thanks to the support of this grant, three graduate students graduated with PhD. Two of these three students are female.
